page.title: 06ECOLOGY IN PANTON
page.content: A very controversial subject both nationally and locally is that of straw burning. Straw burning takes place at {PANTON }as soon as possible after the crops have been harvested. ON heavy clays, this is done to give a good natural weed-control, kill off dormant slugs which can destroy the newly-planted crop, and incorporated ash helps in the nutrition of the tilth. Under the present code farmers may not now burn straw at week-ends or at night or on Bank holidays. They must also make a cultivated strip round the edges of the fields to stop fire spreading to hedges. Burning in some parts of the country has caused traffic accidents. Smuts hang in the air and opponents to burning argue that valuable energy is being wasted, wildlife is being harmed and that the stubble should be ploughed in.
